prompt:
You are provided with a list of characters, evidences and testimonies.
Characters:
Character 0
Name: Maya Fey
Description: My assistant and a disciple in the Kurain Tradition of spirit channeling.
Character 1
Name: Mia Fey
Description: Maya's older sister and my eternal mentor in life and law. Passed away 2 years ago.
Character 2
Name: Godot
Description: A prosecutor who is shrouded in mystery. He seems to know me somehow.
Character 3
Name: Dick Gumshoe
Description: Homicide detective at the local precinct. In charge of the initial investigation.
Character 4
Name: Maggey Byrde
Description: A waitress at Trés Bien. Was found guilty of murder thanks to the phony me.
Character 5
Name: Jean Armstrong
Description: Trés Bien's owner and chef. A witness in the case who is also into aromatherapy.
Character 6
Name: Glen Elg
Description: The victim. Was a programmer. Maggey had apparently never even seen him before.
Character 7
Name: Victor Kudo
Description: Was in Trés Bien at the time of the incident. Has a thing for waitresses.
Character 8
Name: Lisa Basil
Description: The CEO of Blue Screens, Inc., and Glen Elg's boss. Absolutely not a robot.
Character 9
Name: Violetta → Viola Cadaverini
Description: Possibly part of the staff at Tender Lender? A thoroughly bitter person.
Character 10
Name: Furio Tigre
Description: The head of Tender Lender loan company. Also known as "The Tiger".
Character 11
Name: Bruto Cadaverini
Description: The head of the Cadaverini Family crime syndicate. Seems to live for his granddaughter.
Evidences:
Evidence 0
Name: Attorney's Badge
Description: It's my all-important badge. It shows that I am a defense attorney.
Evidence 1
Name: Maya's Magatama
Description: A present from Maya. It reacts to people who have secrets in their hearts. On loan from Maya. Recovered in the kitchen of Trés Bien.
Evidence 2
Name: Magazine Clipping
Description: An article from December 5th. Says I was trounced and my client was found guilty.
Evidence 3
Name: Sports Paper
Description: Dates from December 3rd, the day of the incident. On it is a doodle that said 'MC Bomber' with an arrow pointing to '100,000' that was crossed out. 'Ahahahaha' and a laughing face are written next to it. Left by a costumer in Trés Bien on Dec. 3rd. Click here for details. Left by the victim. Doodle is in victim's handwriting. Click here for details.
Evidence 4
Name: Job Listings
Description: Picked up from a bench in Vitamin Square. Thrown away by the old man.
Evidence 5
Name: Lunch Special
Description: Trés Bien lunch special. Costs 20 dollars despite how unbelievably bad it tastes.
Evidence 6
Name: Small Bottle
Description: Found in the kitchen. Shape is different from the others bottles. Contents unknown. The victim's ear medicine. Found covered in unidentified fingerprints in the kitchen. The victim's ear medicine. Covered in Furio Tigre's fingerprints.
Evidence 7
Name: Scooter
Description: Ridden by my phony. The wheel guard is all smashed up.
Evidence 8
Name: Jean's Loan Contract
Description: Jean's debt is half a million dollars. The owner of the loan is Tender Lender.
Evidence 9
Name: Victor's Note
Description: "Convicted before, a wicked man or woman, repeat offender -- Victor Kudo"
Evidence 10
Name: Glen's Autopsy Report
Description: Died of potassium cyanide poisoning. Time of death was between 1:30 and 2:30 PM.
Evidence 11
Name: Trés Bien Floor Plans
Description: Blueprints of the crime scene. Click here for details. X = victim's seat.
Evidence 12
Name: Crime Photo
Description: A photo of the scene taken from near the kitchen. Two dining tables are separated by a folding screen. The one closer to the camera is empty. The other one is where the victim collapse on the table. There is an intact vase on each table. A coffee cup is knocked over and the the table cloth is stained by coffee. Near the coffee table are some pieces of papers. No one is sitting across from the victim.
Evidence 13
Name: Coffee Cup
Description: The coffee contained potassium cyanide. Covered in the victim and Maggey's fingerprints. Facing the cup, one can see a lip stain on the front, and a floral looking handle to the right.
Evidence 14
Name: Victim's Lottery Ticket
Description: A winning ticket for half a million dollars. Found during a body search of Maggey.
Evidence 15
Name: Apron
Description: Worn by Maggey at the time of the incident. Has small pockets but big stains.
Evidence 16
Name: Potassium Cyanide
Description: A deadly powdery poison. Bears Maggey's fingerprints. Found in her apron pocket.
Evidence 17
Name: Victim's Prescription Bag
Description: The victim got this from the doctor before going to Trés Bien. The bag is empty.
There was a prescription bag on the victim's table along with the lottery ticket.
Evidence 18
Name: Victor's Testimony
Description: "When the incident occurred, I broke the vase at my seat. I'm sorry."
Evidence 19
Name: Millionaire Radio Flyer
Description: Experience the most thrilling ten minutes of your life every Monday at 1:30 PM!
Evidence 20
Name: Glen's Calendar
Description: On Dec. 3rd, the day of the incident, there is a note saying, "Meet with The Tiger".
Evidence 21
Name: Losing Horse Racing Tickets
Description: Horse racing betting tickets. Found in Glen Elg's desk. There's over 500 of them!
Evidence 22
Name: Gumshoe's Lunchbox
Description: A tenderly handmade lunchbox. Fills the stomach with love and plenty of weenies.
Evidence 23
Name: MC Bomber
Description: Found at Tender Lender. A sample disc with the name written in marker. Found at Tender Lender. Contains a computer virus program. A computer virus made by Glen Elg. Potentially worth million of dollars.
Evidence 24
Name: Trés Bien Matches
Description: Matches used for advertising. Found lying in Tender Lender.
Evidence 25
Name: Repair Bill
Description: A car repair bill for $15,000. Paid by Tigre to the Cadaverini Family.
Evidence 26
Name: Paper Badge
Description: Found at Tender Lender. Made of cardboard and painted to look authentic.
Evidence 27
Name: Viola's Medical Papers
Description: A 1 million dollar bill for cranial surgery. Payment was due last year.

Testimonies:
Testimony 0
Testimony: The crime was reported at 2:25 PM by a kind of scary old man, sir.
Person: Gumshoe
Testimony 1
Testimony: Poor Maggey had passed out from the shock. It must've been real tough for her.
Person: Gumshoe
Testimony 2
Testimony: The victim didn't have any identification on him.
Person: Gumshoe
Testimony 3
Testimony: But we figured out who he was pretty quick, and then the investigation went smoothly.
Person: Gumshoe
Testimony 4
Testimony: When Maggey was searched, we found the lottery ticket and the bottle of poison.
Person: Gumshoe
Testimony 5
Testimony: And that was it. There was nothing else missing from the crime scene.
Person: Gumshoe

Which evidence and testimony contradict each other? You must only answer one pair. You may output an explanation, but your answer must end with a JSON format like so: {"evidence": 2, "testimony": 3}. The answer JSON should strictly be the last line, followed by nothing else.
cot:
Okay, let's tackle this problem. So, the user wants to find which evidence and testimony contradict each other. They provided a list of characters, evidences, and testimonies. The task is to find one pair where the evidence contradicts a testimony. Let's start by going through each testimony and see if any evidence directly contradicts it.

First, let's look at the testimonies given by Gumshoe. Testimony 3 says, "But we figured out who he was pretty quick, and then the investigation went smoothly." The key point here is that the police identified the victim quickly. However, looking at Evidence 2, which is the Magazine Clipping. The description says it's an article from December 5th stating that "I" (probably the attorney) was trounced and the client (Maggey) was found guilty. Wait, but the crime happened on December 3rd, as per Evidence 3 (Sports Paper). The clipping is from two days later. But how does that relate to Testimony 3?

Wait, Testimony 3 is about identifying the victim quickly. But Evidence 2 is about the attorney losing the case. Maybe not the right pair. Let me check other testimonies.

Testimony 2: The victim didn't have any identification on him. But Evidence 17, the Victim's Prescription Bag, says there was a prescription bag on the victim's table. Prescription bags usually have the patient's name. So if the victim didn't have ID, but the prescription bag was there with his name, then that's a contradiction. Wait, but Testimony 2 says the victim didn't have ID on him. But the prescription bag could have his name. So if the police found the prescription bag, they would know his identity quickly, which would support Testimony 3. Wait, but Testimony 2 says they didn't have ID, but maybe the prescription bag was present, which could have his name. So perhaps Testimony 3 (they identified him quickly) is explained by the prescription bag (Evidence 17) being found. But Testimony 2 says no ID, but Evidence 17 is a prescription bag. So that might be a contradiction. If the prescription bag was on the table, then the victim's name would be there, so why did they have to figure it out later? Hmm.

Alternatively, let's look at Testimony 5: "And that was it. There was nothing else missing from the crime scene." But Evidence 14 is the Victim's Lottery Ticket found on Maggey. The lottery ticket was a winning one for half a million. If the victim had it, but it was found on Maggey, then that implies something was missing from the crime scene. But according to Testimony 5, nothing else was missing. So if the lottery ticket was originally the victim's, then it's missing from the scene and found on Maggey, contradicting Testimony 5. That seems like a contradiction. So Evidence 14 (lottery ticket found on Maggey) contradicts Testimony 5 (nothing else missing). But wait, the testimony says "nothing else missing", but the lottery ticket was taken from the scene (found on Maggey). Therefore, the ticket was missing from the scene, so Testimony 5 is false. That could be the pair.

Another possibility: Testimony 5 says nothing else was missing, but Evidence 17 mentions that the victim's prescription bag was on the table along with the lottery ticket. But then the lottery ticket was found on Maggey, so it was taken from the scene. Hence, Testimony 5 is contradicted by Evidence 14. So Evidence 14 and Testimony 5 would be the pair.

Alternatively, Testimony 0: The crime was reported at 2:25 PM by a scary old man. But Evidence 19 is the Millionaire Radio Flyer, which mentions an event every Monday at 1:30 PM. If the incident happened on Dec 3rd, which was a Monday (as per Evidence 3's date), then the time of death was between 1:30 and 2:30 PM (Evidence 10). The event at 1:30 PM might be relevant. But how does that contradict the testimony? The testimony is about the time of the report, which is after the time of death. Maybe not directly related.

Looking back at Testimony 3: "figured out who he was pretty quick". But Evidence 20 is Glen's Calendar with a note to meet "The Tiger" (Furio Tigre) on Dec 3rd. If the police found that, they could identify the victim through his calendar. But Testimony 3 is about identification. Not sure if that contradicts.

Another angle: Testimony 4 says that when Maggey was searched, they found the lottery ticket and the poison. Evidence 14 is the lottery ticket found on Maggey, and Evidence 16 is the poison in her apron. So Testimony 4 is supported by those evidences. No contradiction there.

Wait, Testimony 5 says "nothing else missing from the crime scene". But the lottery ticket was originally part of the crime scene (as per Evidence 17: the prescription bag and lottery ticket were on the victim's table). If the lottery ticket was found on Maggey, then it was taken from the scene, hence missing. Therefore, Testimony 5 is contradicted by Evidence 14. That seems solid. So the pair would be Evidence 14 and Testimony 5.

Alternatively, let's check other possibilities. Testimony 5: "nothing else missing". But Evidence 3 is the Sports Paper left by the victim. If the Sports Paper was left there, but the doodle on it mentions 'MC Bomber' which is a virus program (Evidence 23). If the Sports Paper was part of the crime scene, then Testimony 5's statement holds. But maybe not a contradiction here.

Another thought: Testimony 2 says the victim didn't have ID, but Evidence 17's prescription bag was on the table. The prescription bag would have his name. So if the police found the prescription bag, they could identify him, which would align with Testimony 3. But Testimony 2 says no ID, which is different from the prescription bag. Maybe the prescription bag is not considered ID, so no contradiction.

So the strongest contradiction is between Testimony 5 (nothing missing) and Evidence 14 (lottery ticket found on Maggey, implying it was taken from the scene). Therefore, that's the pair.

Testimony: There wasn't anything that caught my interest about her when I saw her from the front.

cot:
Okay, let's tackle this problem. So, I need to find which evidence and testimony contradict each other. The user wants one pair. Let me start by going through the testimonies and matching them against the evidence provided.

First, looking at the Testimonies. Testimony 0 to 6 are all from Kudo (Victor Kudo). Let's go through each one. 

Testimony 1 and 2 are about Maggey putting white powder in the victim's drink. The evidence related to the poison is Evidence 16 (Potassium Cyanide in Maggey's apron) and Evidence 13 (Coffee Cup with her fingerprints). But according to Testimony 2, Kudo says Maggey put white powder in the coffee. However, Evidence 13 says the coffee had potassium cyanide, which is a powdery poison. That seems consistent. Wait, but wait—the Coffee Cup is covered in Maggey's fingerprints, which would support her handling it. But maybe there's a contradiction elsewhere.

Looking at Testimony 5: Kudo mentions the apron's straps were loose. Evidence 15 (Apron) has small pockets with big stains. If the straps were loose, maybe the poison could have been planted? Not sure yet.

Testimony 3: The victim took a sip, looked in pain, and collapsed. The autopsy (Evidence 10) says death was between 1:30 and 2:30 PM due to potassium cyanide. That matches.

Wait, Testimony 0 says the young man (victim, Glen) was reading the sports paper. Evidence 3 is the Sports Paper with a doodle by the victim. The doodle has 'MC Bomber' linked to '100,000' crossed out. Evidence 23 is MC Bomber, a computer virus made by Glen. Also, Evidence 20 (Glen's Calendar) mentions meeting with "The Tiger" (Furio Tigre) on the day of the incident. The Sports Paper has the victim's handwriting. So, if the victim was reading the sports paper, which had his own doodle, maybe that's a clue.

But where's the contradiction? Let's check Testimony 2 again. Kudo claims he saw Maggey put white powder in the drink. But maybe the poison was in something else. Wait, Evidence 6 is a Small Bottle found in the kitchen, which is the victim's ear medicine. But it's covered in Furio Tigre's fingerprints. If the victim's ear medicine was in the kitchen, but the actual poisoning was via the coffee, maybe there's a contradiction here. Wait, but the autopsy says potassium cyanide, which was in the coffee (Evidence 13). The Small Bottle's contents are unknown, but it's the ear medicine. So maybe the real poison was the coffee, not the ear medicine. But why is the ear medicine in the kitchen with Tigre's fingerprints? Hmm.

Wait, another angle: Testimony 2 says Maggey put white powder in the coffee, but Evidence 16 says the potassium cyanide was found in her apron. However, potassium cyanide is a powder. So if she put the powder in the coffee, then the cup should have her fingerprints, which it does (Evidence 13). But maybe there's a contradiction in the way the poison was administered. Wait, maybe the position of the cup's handle? Evidence 13 mentions the coffee cup has a floral handle on the right. If the victim was right-handed, but the lip stain is on the front... Not sure.

Alternatively, Testimony 5 says Maggey's apron straps were loose. Evidence 15 says the apron has small pockets. If the poison was in her pocket, but the straps were loose, someone else could have put it there. But how does that contradict a testimony?

Wait, Testimony 4: Kudo identifies Maggey as the defendant. But Evidence 14 (Victim's Lottery Ticket) was found on Maggey. But maybe the real killer planted it. But that's not a direct contradiction.

Wait, Testimony 6: Kudo says there wasn't anything interesting about her from the front. But if Maggey's apron had big stains (Evidence 15), maybe that's something noticeable. But Kudo didn't mention the stains, but the testimony is about not catching interest. Not sure if that's a contradiction.

Looking at Evidence 3: The Sports Paper's doodle has 'MC Bomber' with '100,000' crossed out and 'ahahaha'. The victim was a programmer (Character 6). Evidence 23 (MC Bomber) is a virus worth millions. So maybe the victim had a deal with Tigre (The Tiger, from Evidence 20), but the crossed out 100k suggests a disagreement. Also, the doodle is on the sports paper from Dec 3rd, the day of the incident.

Wait, Testimony 0 says the victim was reading the sports paper. But the doodle on the sports paper (Evidence 3) is in the victim's handwriting, left by him. So that's consistent. But if the victim was meeting with Tigre (per Evidence 20), and Tigre's fingerprints are on the Small Bottle (Evidence 6), maybe Tigre was involved in poisoning him. But how does that relate to the testimony?

Alternatively, Testimony 1 and 2 say Maggey put powder in the coffee. But Evidence 6 (small bottle) has the victim's ear medicine with Tigre's fingerprints. If the victim needed ear medicine, maybe the poison was in the ear medicine, but the coffee was the method. Or perhaps the poison was administered through the ear? But the autopsy says potassium cyanide poisoning, which is ingested. Hmm.

Wait, Evidence 17 is the Victim's Prescription Bag, empty. So maybe the victim took his ear medicine, but the bottle is in the kitchen. If the bottle was supposed to be with him, but ended up in the kitchen with Tigre's prints, maybe Tigre tampered with it. But again, how does that contradict testimony?

Alternatively, looking at the layout. Evidence 12 (Crime Photo) shows the victim's table with a coffee cup knocked over. The Coffee Cup (Evidence 13) has the victim and Maggey's fingerprints. The lip stain is on the front, handle to the right. If the victim was right-handed, the handle would be on the right. So when he drank, the lip stain would be on the front. That seems okay. But maybe the position of the cup when served? If Maggey served it, but the handle was on the right, then the victim would have to turn it to drink. But that's speculative.

Wait, Testimony 5 mentions a ribbon in her hair and loose apron straps. Evidence 15's apron has big stains. If the apron had big stains, Kudo might have noticed that, but he didn't mention it. But Testimony 6 says nothing caught his interest when he saw her from the front. If the apron had big stains, that might be noticeable. So maybe contradiction between Testimony 6 (nothing interesting) and Evidence 15 (apron with big stains). But the user might consider that a contradiction. However, "big stains" could be on the front, which Kudo would have seen. If he says there was nothing interesting, but there were big stains, that's a contradiction. That might be a possible pair: Evidence 15 (Apron) and Testimony 6.

Alternatively, Testimony 2 says Maggey put white powder in the coffee. Evidence 13 says the coffee had potassium cyanide, which is a white powder. But Evidence 16 says the poison was found in her apron. So if she put the powder in the coffee, there should be residue in the coffee, which there is. But the presence of the poison in her apron could imply she had it, but maybe she didn't use it. But the testimony says she did. So maybe no contradiction here.

Wait, Evidence 6: Small Bottle (ear medicine) has Furio's fingerprints. If the victim's ear medicine was in the kitchen, and Furio handled it, maybe he tampered with it. But the cause of death was poisoning via coffee. So perhaps the real method was the coffee, but Furio was involved with the ear medicine. Not directly contradicting testimony.

Another angle: Testimony 0 says the victim was reading the sports paper. The Sports Paper (Evidence 3) was left by the victim on Dec 3rd. The doodle is in his handwriting. But the Sports Paper's date is Dec 3rd, the day of the incident. So if the victim was reading it at the time, that's consistent. No contradiction there.

Wait, Evidence 3's doodle has 'MC Bomber' with 100,000 crossed out and laughter. Evidence 23 (MC Bomber) is a virus worth millions. So maybe the victim was trying to sell it for 100k but then decided to ask for more, leading to conflict. The meeting with "The Tiger" (Furio) on the calendar (Evidence 20) suggests they met. If Furio wanted the virus but didn't want to pay, maybe he killed Glen. But how does that tie into the testimonies?

If Furio was involved, perhaps he framed Maggey. The Lottery Ticket (Evidence 14) found on Maggey was worth half a million, which is the same amount as Jean's loan (Evidence 8). Maybe Furio planted the ticket on her to frame her. But how does this relate to a contradiction between testimony and evidence?

Hmm. Let's think about the timeline. The victim died between 1:30 and 2:30 PM (Evidence 10). The Millionaire Radio Flyer (Evidence 19) mentions a thrilling ten minutes every Monday at 1:30 PM. Maybe the radio show is a distraction or alibi. Not sure.

Wait, Evidence 7 is the Scooter ridden by the phony (probably Furio, since he's the head of Tender Lender and the Paper Badge, Evidence 26, was found there). The repair bill (Evidence 25) paid by Tigre to Cadaverini. So maybe Furio was impersonating someone?

Back to the main question: Find a testimony and evidence that directly contradict each other. Let's look at Testimony 2: Kudo claims Maggey put white powder in the coffee. But Evidence 6 (Small Bottle) is the victim's ear medicine with Furio's fingerprints. If the actual poison was in the ear medicine, not the coffee, then Testimony 2 is false. But the autopsy says the cause was potassium cyanide in the coffee. So maybe the contradiction is elsewhere.

Wait, Evidence 13 says the Coffee Cup has Maggey's and the victim's fingerprints. If Maggey put the poison in the coffee, her fingerprints would be on the cup. That's consistent. But if the Small Bottle (Evidence 6) has Furio's fingerprints, maybe he was the one who poisoned the ear medicine. But the autopsy says it's the coffee. So maybe the real poison was in the ear medicine, but the coffee was a decoy. That would contradict the autopsy. But the autopsy clearly states potassium cyanide in the coffee.

Alternatively, if the Small Bottle's contents were the ear medicine, but someone replaced it with poison. But Evidence 6 says it's the victim's ear medicine. The contents are unknown but the bottle is covered in Furio's prints. If the ear medicine was laced with poison, but the victim died from the coffee, that's conflicting. But the autopsy says potassium cyanide in the coffee. So maybe the ear medicine is unrelated.

Wait, another angle: Testimony 2 states Maggey put white powder in the coffee. But the Coffee Cup (Evidence 13) has a lip stain on the front. If the cup was facing the victim, the handle is on the right. When the victim drinks, the lip stain would be on the side he drank from. If the poison was in the coffee, then when he sipped, he'd ingest it. But if the handle is on the right, the cup's orientation would be such that the lip stain is on the front. That seems plausible.

Wait, but the Small Bottle (Evidence 6) is the victim's ear medicine. If the victim needed to apply ear drops, perhaps he couldn't hear well. Not sure if that's relevant.

Alternatively, Testimony 18 (Victor's Testimony) says he broke the vase at his seat. But the Crime Photo (Evidence 12) shows two vases on each table, both intact. prompt:
You are provided with a list of characters, evidences and testimonies.
Characters:
Character 0
Name: Maya Fey
Description: My assistant and a disciple in the Kurain Tradition of spirit channeling.
Character 1
Name: Mia Fey
Description: Maya's older sister and my eternal mentor in life and law. Passed away 2 years ago.
Character 2
Name: Godot
Description: A prosecutor who is shrouded in mystery. He seems to know me somehow.
Character 3
Name: Dick Gumshoe
Description: Homicide detective at the local precinct. In charge of the initial investigation.
Character 4
Name: Maggey Byrde
Description: A waitress at Trés Bien. Was found guilty of murder thanks to the phony me.
Character 5
Name: Jean Armstrong
Description: Trés Bien's owner and chef. A witness in the case who is also into aromatherapy.
Character 6
Name: Glen Elg
Description: The victim. Was a programmer. Maggey had apparently never even seen him before.
Character 7
Name: Victor Kudo
Description: Was in Trés Bien at the time of the incident. Has a thing for waitresses.
Character 8
Name: Lisa Basil
Description: The CEO of Blue Screens, Inc., and Glen Elg's boss. Absolutely not a robot.
Character 9
Name: Violetta → Viola Cadaverini
Description: Possibly part of the staff at Tender Lender? A thoroughly bitter person.
Character 10
Name: Furio Tigre
Description: The head of Tender Lender loan company. Also known as "The Tiger".
Character 11
Name: Bruto Cadaverini
Description: The head of the Cadaverini Family crime syndicate. Seems to live for his granddaughter.
Evidences:
Evidence 0
Name: Attorney's Badge
Description: It's my all-important badge. It shows that I am a defense attorney.
Evidence 1
Name: Maya's Magatama
Description: A present from Maya. It reacts to people who have secrets in their hearts. On loan from Maya. Recovered in the kitchen of Trés Bien.
Evidence 2
Name: Magazine Clipping
Description: An article from December 5th. Says I was trounced and my client was found guilty.
Evidence 3
Name: Sports Paper
Description: Dates from December 3rd, the day of the incident. On it is a doodle that said 'MC Bomber' with an arrow pointing to '100,000' that was crossed out. 'Ahahahaha' and a laughing face are written next to it. Left by a costumer in Trés Bien on Dec. 3rd. Click here for details. Left by the victim. Doodle is in victim's handwriting. Click here for details.
Evidence 4
Name: Job Listings
Description: Picked up from a bench in Vitamin Square. Thrown away by the old man.
Evidence 5
Name: Lunch Special
Description: Trés Bien lunch special. Costs 20 dollars despite how unbelievably bad it tastes.
Evidence 6
Name: Small Bottle
Description: Found in the kitchen. Shape is different from the others bottles. Contents unknown. The victim's ear medicine. Found covered in unidentified fingerprints in the kitchen. The victim's ear medicine. Covered in Furio Tigre's fingerprints.
Evidence 7
Name: Scooter
Description: Ridden by my phony. The wheel guard is all smashed up.
Evidence 8
Name: Jean's Loan Contract
Description: Jean's debt is half a million dollars. The owner of the loan is Tender Lender.
Evidence 9
Name: Victor's Note
Description: "Convicted before, a wicked man or woman, repeat offender -- Victor Kudo"
Evidence 10
Name: Glen's Autopsy Report
Description: Died of potassium cyanide poisoning. Time of death was between 1:30 and 2:30 PM.
Evidence 11
Name: Trés Bien Floor Plans
Description: Blueprints of the crime scene. Click here for details. X = victim's seat.
Evidence 12
Name: Crime Photo
Description: A photo of the scene taken from near the kitchen. Two dining tables are separated by a folding screen. The one closer to the camera is empty. The other one is where the victim collapse on the table. There is an intact vase on each table. A coffee cup is knocked over and the the table cloth is stained by coffee. Near the coffee table are some pieces of papers. No one is sitting across from the victim.
Evidence 13
Name: Coffee Cup
Description: The coffee contained potassium cyanide. Covered in the victim and Maggey's fingerprints. Facing the cup, one can see a lip stain on the front, and a floral looking handle to the right.
He had a newspaper in his right hand
Evidence 14
Name: Victim's Lottery Ticket
Description: A winning ticket for half a million dollars. Found during a body search of Maggey.
Evidence 15
Name: Apron
Description: Worn by Maggey at the time of the incident. Has small pockets but big stains.
Evidence 16
Name: Potassium Cyanide
Description: A deadly powdery poison. Bears Maggey's fingerprints. Found in her apron pocket.
Evidence 17
Name: Victim's Prescription Bag
Description: The victim got this from the doctor before going to Trés Bien. The bag is empty.
Evidence 18
Name: Victor's Testimony
Description: "When the incident occurred, I broke the vase at my seat. I'm sorry."
Evidence 19
Name: Millionaire Radio Flyer
Description: Experience the most thrilling ten minutes of your life every Monday at 1:30 PM!
Evidence 20
Name: Glen's Calendar
Description: On Dec. 3rd, the day of the incident, there is a note saying, "Meet with The Tiger".
Evidence 21
Name: Losing Horse Racing Tickets
Description: Horse racing betting tickets. Found in Glen Elg's desk. There's over 500 of them!
Evidence 22
Name: Gumshoe's Lunchbox
Description: A tenderly handmade lunchbox. Fills the stomach with love and plenty of weenies.
Evidence 23
Name: MC Bomber
Description: Found at Tender Lender. A sample disc with the name written in marker. Found at Tender Lender. Contains a computer virus program. A computer virus made by Glen Elg. Potentially worth million of dollars.
Evidence 24
Name: Trés Bien Matches
Description: Matches used for advertising. Found lying in Tender Lender.
Evidence 25
Name: Repair Bill
Description: A car repair bill for $15,000. Paid by Tigre to the Cadaverini Family.
Evidence 26
Name: Paper Badge
Description: Found at Tender Lender. Made of cardboard and painted to look authentic.
Evidence 27
Name: Viola's Medical Papers
Description: A 1 million dollar bill for cranial surgery. Payment was due last year.

Testimonies:
Testimony 0
Testimony: He was another of those pesky young types, wearing a broken pair of spectacles.
Person: Kudo
Testimony 1
Testimony: He had a newspaper in his right hand, and the noisy brat kept rustling its pages!
Person: Kudo
Testimony 2
Testimony: The young man was listening to the wireless. I remember that well.
Person: Kudo
Testimony 3
Testimony: Then the serving girl in question brought over the javaccino.
Person: Kudo
Testimony 4
Testimony: The little fidget picked up the cup with his free hand and took a sip.
Person: Kudo

Which evidence and testimony contradict each other? You must only answer one pair. You may output an explanation, but your answer must end with a JSON format like so: {"evidence": 2, "testimony": 3}. The answer JSON should strictly be the last line, followed by nothing else.

Alternatively, Testimony 3 says the serving girl (Maggey) brought over the javaccino. But looking at the evidence, the Coffee Cup (13) contained potassium cyanide. The cup has Maggey's fingerprints, which matches her serving it. So that's consistent.

Wait, let's go back. Testimony 2 says the victim was listening to the wireless. But the victim's calendar (Evidence 20) has a note to meet with "The Tiger" (Furio Tigre) on Dec 3rd. The time of the meeting isn't specified, but the time of death is 1:30-2:30 PM. The Millionaire Radio Flyer (19) is a show at 1:30 PM. Wait, another angle. The Sports Paper (Evidence 3) has a doodle by the victim. The doodle says 'MC Bomber' with an arrow to '100,000' crossed out, and laughter. Evidence 23 (MC Bomber) is a computer virus made by Glen. The doodle was left by the victim in the restaurant. If the victim was doodling on the paper, maybe he wasn't listening to the radio. But Testimony 2 says he was. So that could be a contradiction. Because if he was actively doodling and holding the newspaper, maybe he wasn't simultaneously listening to the wireless. But that's a bit of an assumption. Alternatively, the presence of the doodle on the sports paper (Evidence 3) indicates he was focused on writing/doodling, which might contradict Testimony 2's claim that he was listening to the radio. But this is circumstantial.

Alternatively, looking at Testimony 1: "He had a newspaper in his right hand, and the noisy brat kept rustling its pages!" But the Crime Photo (Evidence 12) shows that the victim had a coffee cup knocked over, and the newspaper was in his right hand. The autopsy report (10) says death by poison in the coffee. The Coffee Cup (13) has Maggey's fingerprints. The issue here is perhaps the presence of the newspaper in his hand. But maybe another contradiction.

Wait, let's check Testimony 3: "Then the serving girl in question brought over the javaccino." The javaccino would be the coffee. The Coffee Cup (13) has Maggey's fingerprints, so that's consistent. But the Sports Paper (Evidence 3) was left by the victim on Dec 3rd. The doodle is in the victim's handwriting. The doodle includes 'MC Bomber' and '100,000' crossed out. The MC Bomber (Evidence 23) is a virus worth millions. The victim's lottery ticket (14) is for half a million. Maybe the contradiction is elsewhere.

Alternatively, let's think about the layout. The Crime Photo (12) shows two tables separated by a folding screen. The victim's table has the coffee cup, and the other table is empty. Victor Kudo's Testimony 18 says he broke the vase at his seat. But the Crime Photo shows intact vases on both tables. So if Victor broke his vase, why is it intact in the photo? So holding the cup with left hand would mean the handle is on the right, which might be awkward. But this is about the cup's orientation. If the cup's handle is on the right, and he's using his left hand, he might have to reach over, which could leave the lip stain on the front. But the evidence says the lip stain is on the front. Hmm. Wait, the Coffee Cup (13) description says: "Facing the cup, one can see a lip stain on the front, and a floral looking handle to the right." If the victim picked it up with his left hand, the handle would be on his right, which is the same as the description. But the lip stain's position depends on how he sipped. Maybe if he used his left hand, the lip stain would be on the left side, but the evidence says it's on the front. So this might be a contradiction. Because if he used his left hand to bring the cup to his mouth, the lip stain would be on the left side, not the front. But the cup's lip stain is on the front. Therefore, if the testimony says he used his free (left) hand to sip, but the lip stain is on the front, that's a contradiction. Because using the left hand would rotate the cup so that the lip stain is on the left, not front. Alternatively, maybe the front is relative to the handle. If the handle is on the right, then the front is where the lip stain is. So if he used his left hand, the handle is on the right, and he brings the cup to his mouth, the front would still have the lip stain. Maybe not a contradiction.

Alternatively, maybe the key contradiction is between Testimony 2 (listening to wireless) and the Sports Paper (Evidence 3). If the victim was doodling on the paper, he couldn't be holding a radio. Alternatively, the victim's calendar (Evidence 20) says he was meeting with The Tiger (Furio Tigre) on the day of the incident. If the meeting was during the time he was at Trés Bien, then perhaps he was there to meet Furio, not to listen to the radio. But that's speculative.

Hmm. Let me think again. The user wants one pair. The most direct contradiction. Let's look at Testimony 2: Victim was listening to the wireless. But Evidence 19 (Millionaire Radio Flyer) is a radio show that airs at 1:30 PM on Mondays. The incident happened on Dec 3rd, which is the day of the week? If Dec 3rd was a Monday, then the show would be at 1:30 PM. The time of death is 1:30-2:30 PM. So the victim could have been listening to the show at 1:30 PM. But if the victim was at the restaurant to meet Furio Tigre (Evidence 20), then he might have been there for the meeting, not to listen to the radio. But that's not necessarily a contradiction.

Alternatively, the Sports Paper (Evidence 3) from Dec 3rd has a doodle made by the victim. If he was actively doodling during the time of the radio show, he might not have been paying attention to the radio. But this is an assumption.

Wait, but the key contradiction could be between Testimony 2 (listening to wireless) and Evidence 3 (victim's doodle on the paper). The idea is that he couldn't be both doodling and listening to the radio at the same time. But that's not a solid contradiction. People can multitask.

Alternatively, looking at the Coffee Cup (Evidence 13): the victim had a newspaper in his right hand. Testimony 4 says he picked up the cup with his free hand (left), which would align with holding the newspaper in the right. But the cup's handle is on the right side. So using the left hand to pick up the cup would require reaching across the handle, making it awkward. If the handle is on the right, the natural way is to use the right hand. So if the victim used his left hand, the handle's position would be problematic, suggesting that the testimony is wrong. Therefore, Testimony 4 contradicts Evidence 13.

So Testimony 4 says he used his free hand (left) to pick up the cup. But the cup's handle is on the right. So normally, you'd use your right hand to hold the handle. If he used his left hand, the handle would be on the opposite side. The lip stain is on the front. If he used his left hand, the lip stain would be on the left side. But the evidence says it's on the front. Therefore, this is a contradiction. Therefore, the testimony that he used his left hand (free hand) contradicts the position of the lip stain and handle on the cup.

Thus, the correct pair would be Evidence 13 (Coffee Cup) and Testimony 4.

Testimony 0
Testimony: First of all, I want to stress that this might be nothing. I'm not too sure of myself.
Person: Kudo
Testimony 1
Testimony: The young boy slumped over the table as soon as he took one sip of his javaccino...
Person: Kudo
Testimony 2
Testimony: Well, the clumsy idiot upset the vase. He knocked it right over.
Person: Kudo
Testimony 3
Testimony: It broke, and the strip of cloth covering the table got completely soaked!
Person: Kudo
Testimony 4
Testimony: Well!? How about that? Turned things upside-down, hmm?
Person: Kudo

Which evidence and testimony contradict each other? You must only answer one pair. You may output an explanation, but your answer must end with a JSON format like so: {"evidence": 2, "testimony": 3}. The answer JSON should strictly be the last line, followed by nothing else.
cot:
Okay, let me try to figure this out. The user is asking which evidence and testimony contradict each other. The characters, evidences, and testimonies are all provided. I need to go through them one by one to find inconsistencies.

First, looking at the testimonies. All the testimonies given are from Kudo (Victor Kudo). Let's check each testimony:

Testimony 0: He's unsure, maybe not relevant. Testimony 1: Says the victim slumped over after sipping the coffee. Testimony 2: Mentions a clumsy idiot (maybe himself) upsetting a vase. Testimony 3: The vase broke, soaking the table cloth. Testimony 4: He's challenging someone, maybe about the overturned vase.

Now, looking at the evidence. The Crime Photo (Evidence 12) shows that there's an intact vase on each table. But according to Testimony 2 and 3, Kudo broke a vase. That seems contradictory. The photo shows intact vases, but his testimony says he broke one. That must be the contradiction. So Evidence 12 (Crime Photo) and Testimony 2 or 3. Which one?

Wait, Testimony 3 says the cloth got soaked from the broken vase. But the Crime Photo says both vases are intact. So the testimony about breaking the vase (Testimony 2 or 3) contradicts the photo evidence. Specifically, Testimony 2 says he knocked over the vase, which would break it, but the photo shows both vases intact. So Evidence 12 (Crime Photo) contradicts Testimony 2. But wait, the Crime Photo's description mentions that there's a coffee cup knocked over, but the vases are intact. So the broken vase should be visible in the photo, but it's not. So the testimony about breaking the vase (Testimony 2) contradicts the evidence that both vases are intact (Evidence 12). Therefore, the correct pair is Evidence 12 and Testimony 2. Let me confirm the evidence numbers: Evidence 12 is the Crime Photo. Testimony 2 is "Well, the clumsy idiot upset the vase. He knocked it right over." That's a contradiction because the photo shows intact vases. So the answer should be evidence 12 and testimony 2.
